greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Expansion of Product_{k>=0} (1 + x^(7*k+1)).
comment: Number of partitions of n into distinct parts congruent to 1 mod 7.
link: Vaclav Kotesovec, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Vaclav Kotesovec, A method of finding the asymptotics of q-series based on the convolution of generating functions, arXiv:1509.08708 [math.CO], Sep 30 2015.
Index entries for related partition-counting sequences
formula: a(n) ~ exp(Pi*sqrt(n)/sqrt(21))/(2*2^(1/7)*21^(1/4)*n^(3/4)) * (1 + (13*Pi/(336*sqrt(21)) - 3*sqrt(21)/(8*Pi)) / sqrt(n)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jan 03 2017, extended by _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jan 24 2017
mathematica: nmax = 105; CoefficientList[Series[Product[(1 + x^(7 k + 1)), {k, 0, nmax}], {x, 0, nmax}], x]

nmax = 200; poly = ConstantArray[0, nmax + 1]; poly[[1]] = 1; poly[[2]] = 1; Do[If[Mod[k, 7] == 1, Do[poly[[j + 1]] += poly[[j - k + 1]], {j, nmax, k, -1}]; ], {k, 2, nmax}]; poly (* _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jan 18 2017 *)
results.author: _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jan 03 2017
